I wrote a book, dear Berchtolde, a few years ago, I believe, called "On the Method of Study", dealing with both theological and secular literature. It is now in Constance or Geneva with Leonard Hospinian, an erudite young man, whether he is copying it or sharing it with others. However, I have not yet received it back as I had hoped and expected. I had wanted to send it to you as soon as it was returned. This is why I have delayed responding to your questions about the method of study for so long. However, take these few things that we can do, since it is not possible to do what we want.
First of all, divide the day into parts, in which you will fulfill your ecclesiastical duties, take care of your body by eating, drinking, walking or taking your leisure, listen to those who visit you, give them advice, and discuss questions with them, and be diligent in both sacred and secular literature. In the morning devote yourself to more serious and sacred studies. In the afternoon devote yourself to secular studies. After lunch and dinner, answer those who visit us, as is often the case. You will find that, with this partition of time, all effort is somehow alleviated and that many things can be done quickly.
When reading sacred texts, begin with faithful prayer. I do not want you to read in the way of some people, who now read the Old Testament, then the New Testament, then consult commentaries, and then start something else. Follow the order that you have established for yourself in reading, so that in one year you can go through the entire biblical volume. This reading, if you are alert, will not be tedious, but a joy, especially if you commit yourself to God and your life.

It now lurks in Constance or Strassbourg, with Leonard Hospinian, a most learned youth, whether he transcribes it or communicates it to others. Among philosophers, if you look at Christian religion, none is more similar to our own than Lucius Annaeus Seneca. He must be read first and foremost. Cicero's works should accompany him; he was a man of a pleasant and agreeable wit, and he succinctly, clearly, and easily gathers what is intricately taught by various philosophers with the most instructive eloquence. But if you want something more solid and a professed philosopher, read Plato. For just as Cicero excels in oratory, so Plato excels in philosophy. This may be relevant to show which philosophers should be read especially among Christians, that is, which ones have treated the head of Christian philosophy outside the scriptures, that is, without interpreting the scriptures. Therefore, read first of all Tertullian's book "On the Prescription of Heretics," then the one written "Against Praxeas" on the Trinity, then the one written "On the Flesh of Christ" and "On the Resurrection of the Flesh," and the "Apology" against the Gentiles. To accompany these, join two of the most famous books by the truly great Athanasius, written against the Gentiles, and the very eloquent and pious six books by Lucius Coelius Lactantius Firmianus "On Divine Institution." The seventh should be read more critically, since it is chiliastic. On chiliasm, read Eusebius' "Ecclesiastical History" book 3, last chapter, and book 7, chapter 22. To these, add the learned Augustine's books "On Christian Doctrine," in the first place the very polished "On the City of God" books, etc. If you want variety, read Coelius Rhodiginus' "Antique Lectures," Erasmus' "Chiliades," the very elaborate and necessary Pliny and Volaterranus. I am only mentioning the most select, which are enough for a student. For I do not approve of a great number of books, nor the reading of many books in vain, but of select books, so that you may have and read in a few what is necessary to a student, and what others hardly understand from hundreds of books, you may easily get from a single decade of books.
Furthermore, poetry delights, moves, and paints beautifully, even clearly, those who are wicked with wickedness. Therefore, read it for pleasure, so as to relieve the tedium of your studies, and yet observe the force of speaking and learn the manners of men. However, I wish that certain ones should be read by you: Homer, Virgil, Horace, especially Terence, and Ovid.
But dialectic and rhetoric, without which all study is in vain, should not be neglected. I mean dialectic not the Spanish or syllogistic, or such as is taught in universities, but a thread of speaking, so that anyone may truly, copiously, clearly, firmly, and beautifully discourse on any subject. This was sufficiently well indicated by Melanchton, but no one more excellently than Rodolphus Agricola, who wrote three books "On Dialectic Invention" - rhetoric is taught by the same Melanchton in three books, and by Trapezuntius in five books - books, I say, both learned and perspicuous, but no one has yet surpassed Cicero. He who desires a brief summary of all these should read Erasmus' second book "On the Copia of Things" and, in the end, Quintilian's "Institutes of Oratory," and yet these I especially wish to be commended.
But on all these we have copiously and to nausea written in the book which we cited above and inscribed "On the Ratio of Study." I could not say more at present.
